metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Georeferenced raster data from the Dr. Oscar I. Norwich collection of maps of Africa and its islands, 1486 - ca. 1865

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This map is a georeferenced raster image of an historic paper map of Southern Africa from 1892. The original map was included in Rand, McNally and Company's Indexed Atlas of the World and covers the modern day countries of South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland, along with parts of adjacent Mozambique, Namibia and Botswana. The original map identifies cities and towns, rivers, mountains and other topographical features, as well as historic sites, such as the diamond fields of Griqualand West. This map is part of a selection of digitally scanned and georeferenced historic maps of Africa from the Oscar I. Norwich Collection at Stanford University.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: This is a historic map of Southern Africa from the 19th Century. This map has been georeferenced and can be used as a layer in ArcGIS.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Rand McNally and Company and Stanford Geospatial Center. (2013). Map of South Africa, 1892 (Raster Image). Stanford Digital Repository.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Images may be reproduced or transmitted, but not for commercial use.” For commercial use or commercial republication, contact brannerlibrary@stanford.edu. Attribution-Non Commercial: CC BY-NC."

title.gco:CharacterString: Georeferenced raster data from the Dr. Oscar I. Norwich collection of maps of Africa and its islands, 1486 - ca. 1865

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The collection contains georeferenced maps of Africa and its islands collected by Oscar I. Norwich, and includes sea charts and maps of Southern Africa; the Cape of Good Hope; North, East, and West Africa; islands, ports, and town plans.

title.gco:CharacterString: Dr. Oscar I. Norwich collection of maps of Africa and its islands, 1486 - ca. 1865

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The collection contains 311 maps of Africa and its islands collected by Oscar I. Norwich, and includes sea charts and maps of Southern Africa; the Cape of Good Hope; North, East, and West Africa; islands, ports, and town plans. The majority of the maps are loose items, but a certain number are from rare, published atlases; a few were published in travel books.

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.1.0.3035

gml:UnitDefinition.gml:identifier: Unified Code of Units of Measure

evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The georeferenced raster is a faithfully reproduced digital image of the original source map. Some differences may be detected between the source graphic used and the raster image due to the RGB values assigned that particular color. The intent is to recreate those colors as near as possible.

The horizontal positional accuracy of a raster image is approximately the same as the accuracy of the published source map. The lack of a greater accuracy is largely the result of the inaccuracies with the original measurements and possible distortions in the original paper map document. There may also be errors introduced during the digitizing and georeferencing process. In most cases, however, errors in the raster image are small compared with sources of error in the original map graphic. The RMS error for this map is 708.84 meters. This value describes how consistent the transformation is between the different control points (links). The RMS error is only an assessment of the accuracy of the transformation.
Data completeness for raster digital image files reflect content of the source graphic. Features may have been eliminated or generalized on the source graphic due to scale and legibility constraints.

statement.gco:CharacterString: This map was scanned and georeferenced by the Stanford University Geospatial Center using a Sinusoidal projection. The prime meridian used during the georeferencing process was the Greenwich prime meridian and the central meridian was set at 20, the latitude of origin used for all regional maps was 0°. In the process of georeferencing this map, 4 control points were created. The transformation order used to georeference the map is 1st order.

description.gco:CharacterString: The following spatially referenced data was used during the georeferencing process; it was used for verification purposes: 1) Natural Earth: 1, 5, 15 and 20 degree vector graticules. 2) Natural Earth: 10 meter vector coastline Made with Natural Earth. Free vector and raster map data @ naturalearthdata.com
